dialogue: Mr. Sythe, you just stated you loved Kendall Carter, is that right?
Yes. More than anything.
And on the night of October 25th, you and Kendall drive to Rowdy's Hideaway together. Is that right?
We took my car, yeah.
And when you got there, the two of you started drinking, is that right?
Yes.
And then, the two of you got into an argument, is that right?
Yes.
And during this argument, you knocked a beer bottle off the table, is that right?
Yeah.
Then, she walked out and you went after her. Is that right?
Well yeah, but--

And outside, the two of you continued arguing and it's your sworn testimony that you left her alone so she could walk down a narrow, two-lane road in the dark, drunk, in the pouring rain, during a thunderstorm. Is that how you treat someone you love...?
What are you doing here?
Have a seat.
I shouldn't be talking to you. Resnick nods “it’s okay” to his client. He sits.
Okay, What do you want?
Same thing as you. Justice for Kendall Carter.
Then go find the guy who did it.
No jury, no Judge, no cameras. Tell me what happened that night.
I told you. I went home.
But first you followed her, right?
She was wasted.
And you were angry and sick of getting played.
It wasn’t like that. She just needed to Chill out. That’s how “Kenny” was. She’d get all worked up and talk this big game and then the next day it was like nothing happened.

I've done a lot of things in my life I'm not proud of. But I didn't do this. The biggest regret of my life is not going after Kendall in my car that night. Because if I had, she'd still be alive. He stands up. Looks to Resnick.
I’m done here.
